text: [MUSIC]

>> Hello everybody.
My name is Rob Reich,

and I'm a professor
of Political Science
at Stanford University.
This year is like no other
we've experienced as Americans.
A raging pandemic, social unrest,
deep economic uncertainty,
documented threats of

external interference
in our election,

and all as this election year
is already well underway,
due to many factors,
including our complex and

tangled relationship
with technology.

We have reached the
point of needing to
stand up for democracy itself,

and for the 240 year long
experiment of democracy in
the United States in ways that we

couldn't have imagined
just a few decades ago.

We are going to use the
experience of this class

to raise awareness of all
of these critical issues,

based upon material from a
course on the subject being

run with my colleagues at
Stanford Continuing Studies.

Join me and my co-instructor,
Marietje Schaake,

in this free class
that will help you

understand the
unprecedented influence of

technology and
technology policy on

America's elections and
democratic process.

We will take a close look
at how a public sphere

played by polarization,
online filter bubbles,

echo chambers, political
advertising and much more

impacts our ability to be
well-informed citizens.

Join us to be more
than just a voter,

become an advocate for
a better democracy.
[MUSIC]
